docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna Inc., in one of the largest job cutbacks in the health care and insurance industries, said yesterday that it would reduce its work force by 4,400 jobs, or 13 percent of its 33,700 employees. It was Aetna's fourth big layoff announcement this year. The company, based in Hartford, said it would lay off a total of 8,200, but some of those people would be retrained for 3,800 new positions that it will create. The decision brought the number of overall layoffs planned by Aetna this year to more than 10,800. About 1,000 jobs will be cut in Connecticut.

headline.main: Aetna to Cut 4,400 More Jobs As It Shifts to Managed Care

docs.abstract: Aetna Inc, in one of largest job cutbacks in health care and insurance industries, says that it will reduce its work force by 4,400 jobs, or 13 percent of its 33,700 employees; says it will lay off 8,200, but some of those people will be retrained for 3,800 new positions that it will create; decision brings number of overall layoffs planned by Aetna this year to over 10,800; about 1,000 jobs will be cut in Connecticut; Aetna's downsizing reflects company's struggle to transform itself from provider of traditional insurance and financial services into leader in managed health care; Aetna announced in April that it would spend $8.18 billion to acquire US Healthcare (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna to Trim 4,400 Jobs In Fourth Layoff This Year Aetna, in one of the largest job cutbacks in the health care and insurance industries, said it would reduce its payroll by 4,400 jobs, or 13 percent of its 33,700 work force. The decision brought the number of overall layoffs planned by Aetna this year to more than 10,800. About 1,000 jobs will be cut in Connecticut. $(Page A1.$) Retail Sales Results Mixed Retailers posted another month of mixed sales results, adding to accumulating evidence that there are still too many stores decorating the country's landscape. Not many retailers stood out as true winners or losers as they reported their monthly sales. The exception was merchants of luxury goods, which continued to draw shoppers. $(D3.$) Designer Will Head Ford Operations Ford named Jacques A. Nasser, 48, a group president in charge of vehicle development, to head its North American and European automotive operations. $(D4.$) Stocks Fall on Earnings Worries Stocks slipped further amid growing caution about earnings reports and September's inflation data. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 8.95 points, to 5,921.67. $(D4.$) Treasury prices fell sharply as concerns grew about inflation and interest rates. The yield on the 30-year bond rose to 6.88 percent, from 6.83 percent on Wednesday. $(D14.$) Olin to Spin Off Two Divisions Olin said it planned to spin off and sell some operations and buy back as much as 10 percent of its stock. $(D4.$) G.E. Earnings Rise 11 Percent General Electric posted third-quarter earnings that were 11 percent higher than the performance of the period last year. $(D3.$) Internet Deal for Madison Avenue True North Communications said it would combine its TN Technologies unit, which specializes in interactive marketing communications, with Modem Media in a stock deal worth $29 million. True North also said it planned a public offering of shares in the combined operations. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. $(D2.$) Nuclear Plant Will Remain Closed Northeast Utilities in Connecticut said that it probably would not restart the 28-year-old Connecticut Yankee nuclear power plant because of high costs. $(B1.$) Time Warner-Turner Deal Approved Shareholders of Time Warner and Turner Broadcasting System approved their $7 billion merger. Now, Time Warner faces the more difficult problem of cutting its $17 billion in debt. $(D2.$) J. P. Morgan Has Lower Earnings J. P. Morgan said that its earnings fell 23 percent in the third quarter. $(D3.$) Loewen Board Rejects Buyout Offer The Loewen board unanimously dismissed a hostile $3.2 billion offer from Service Corporation International. $(D3.$)

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK Aetna to Reduce Work Force Aetna Inc., in one of the largest job cutbacks in the health care and insurance industries, said that it would reduce its work force by 4,400 jobs, or 13 percent. $(Page A1.$) Star Treatment for a Boy Jeffrey Maier, the 12-year-old boy with a black baseball glove who reached out of the Yankee Stadium right-field stands in the eighth inning on Wednesday night to rescue victory for the home team from the clutches of imminent defeat, became New York royalty. $(A1.$) Housing: Hope for the Future? The hope for a better future in low-income housing is embodied in Lula West's new two-bedroom apartment in Brooklyn. But the program that gave Miss West a decent and inexpensive home was a product of a bygone era. With money and political will in short supply at every level of government, housing programs have been cut back substantially. Many housing advocates and experts agree that this broad retrenchment will likely lead to more substandard, expensive dwellings. $(B1.$) New Twist for Chinese Refugee Wu Lu Zhong was among the 286 Chinese illegal immigrants who packed themselves in 1993 into the infamous smuggling ship called the Golden Venture, which ran aground off the Rockaway Peninsula in Queens. Now his odyssey has taken a new turn. NYC by Clyde Haberman. $(B1.$) City Moves in Cable Showdown The Giuliani administration began transmitting a 24-hour news channel on a city-run cable station late last night, over the objections of the city's dominant cable operator, Time Warner, and said it would put Rupert Murdoch's Fox News Channel on another city-run station tonight. Time Warner had said it would block both channels, but its subscribers received the Bloomberg station on Channel 71. $(B1.$) Fire Drives NBC Into Street Katie Couric did the ''Today'' show as a sidewalk standup, network producers held curbside staff meetings, writers scribbled alfresco in longhand and news anchors broadcast in a drizzle with firefighters scurrying in the background as an electrical fire drove NBC from its headquarters at Rockefeller Center. $(B3.$) Mayor to Fight Welfare Rules Having received national attention for his vigorous defense of immigration, Mayor Giuliani announced the formation of a coalition of prominent New Yorkers to help him lead the fight against provisions of the new Federal welfare law that he views as anti-immigrant. $(B3.$) 'Kissing Schoolboy' in Trouble The Queens schoolboy who kissed a classmate and became part of a national furor over the meaning of sexual harassment has become the subject of a new dispute over discipline between local school officials and the central school administration. School officials in Queens said they tried to suspend the boy, De'Andre Dearinge, after he bit and punched a teacher at his Far Rockaway elementary school, but were blocked from doing so by the Board of Education. $(B5.$) Examining the Livoti Case If there was a moment when the prosecution began to lose its case against Officer Francis X. Livoti, who was accused of fatally choking Anthony Baez, perhaps it was when the Chief Medical Examiner, Dr. Charles S. Hirsch, testified that the main cause of death was asphyxia because of compression of the neck and chest. Then Acting Justice Gerald Sheindlin of State Supreme Court broke in with a hypothetical question. $(B5.$) The leader of the female wing of the Latin Kings, one of New York City's most notorious criminal gangs, pleaded guilty in Federal court to charges of conspiracy to murder and assault, less than a week before she and other gang members were scheduled for trial. $(B3.$) CONNECTICUT A Region's Turning Point Only a year or so ago, the dealers, waitresses and cashiers at the new Mohegan Sun casino were welders, machinists, nurses and engineers, working for companies that were laying people off or closing whole divisions. For them, and southeastern Connecticut, the opening of the casino today offers a ray of hope. $(B1.$) Economics Drives Nuclear Issue For many years, the debate about nuclear energy in America has been framed by concerns about the environment. But the decision by Northeast Utilities in Connecticut that it probably will not restart the 28-year-old Connecticut Yankee nuclear power plant in Haddam Neck suggests that the environmental arguments are no longer the prime mover. Accountants now call the tune. $(B6.$) NEW JERSEY Embassy Knew About Fugitive In the latest twist in a case that has entangled the Senate campaign of Representative Robert G. Torricelli, a former official at the American Embassy in Seoul confirmed that the embassy knew in 1986 the whereabouts of a fugitive who had ties to the Congressman. $(B6.$)

docs.lead_paragraph: John P. Dougherty, the president of the Stark County board of commissioners, Scott Oelslager, the State Senator from this area, as well as Jim Craig, Ken McPeek, Sally Efremoff and Fred Krum, all longtime local school board members, are moderate suburban Republicans who voted for George Bush in 1992. And they have all had the same basic reaction as they have listened to Bob Dole repeatedly single out the teachers' unions as the major obstacle to education reform in this country. ''Senator Dole should not have made that comment,'' Senator Oelslager said. ''The teachers' union -- they're our friends,'' said Ms. Efremoff, who spent 14 years on the school board in Plain, a township that votes Republican in Presidential elections.

headline.main: Dole's Attacks on Teacher Unions Hit Sour Note for Some Ohio Republicans

docs.abstract: Article in series on Presidential race in Canton, Ohio, and surrounding Stark County focuses on how Bob Dole's repeated attacks on teachers' unions as obstacle to education reform have upset some moderate suburban Republicans; county's teachers unions have helped introduce innovative programs; suburbanites oppose threats to public education, including Dole's call for publicly financed vouchers to enable children to attend private schools; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the one of the biggest Medicare fraud settlements involving a clinical laboratory company, Corning Inc. agreed yesterday in Boston to plead guilty to Federal fraud charges and pay $119 million in criminal fines and civil penalties. The Government said the settlement covered ''literally millions of fraudulent claims'' at Damon Clinical Laboratories Inc., which Corning acquired in 1993. Corning said the claims involved marketing and billing practices at the laboratories before Corning acquired them.

headline.main: Corning Will Plead Guilty to Medicare Fraud

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your Business Day article ''Not Quite What the Doctor Ordered'' (Oct. 8) alleges that managed-care organizations often make changes to a prescription drug order without first getting the doctor's consent. But as you point out, what pharmacists may or may not do in this arena is governed by state law.

headline.main: H.M.O.'s Switch Drugs, but Not Just for Price

docs.lead_paragraph: ''I TRUST the people,'' remonstrated Bill Clinton in response to Bob Dole's charge during Sunday's Presidential debate that he put more faith in government. ''But I do think we are right when we try to, for example, give mothers and newborns 48 hours before they can be kicked out of the hospital,'' Mr. Clinton added. Don't expect Mr. Dole to press the issue of the President's inclination to depend on Washington to end what Mr. Clinton called ''drive-by deliveries.'' After all, it was Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey, a rising star in the Republican Party, who led the drive at the state level to bar health maintenance organizations from sending mothers and newborns home without a second day to recuperate. Remember, too, that parallel Federal legislation, signed by the President in September, was widely supported by Congressional Republicans.

headline.main: When politicians seek to please on medical benefits.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The article ''Not Quite What the Doctor Ordered'' (Business Day, Oct. 8) reinforced my dismay regarding the changing health-care industry. As a primary-care physician, I receive annoying calls from pharmaceutical managed-care companies asking me to change a patient from one drug to another for ''cost savings.''

docs.lead_paragraph: This is a 30-second commercial that Representative Richard A. Zimmer, the Republican nominee for the United States Senate seat in New Jersey, began broadcasting on Sunday. Mr. Zimmer's Democratic opponent is Representative Robert G. Torricelli. PRODUCER -- Jamestown Associates, Princeton ON THE SCREEN -- Seated in front of a computer screen, a man, identified as ''net surfer,'' clicks his mouse on the word ''liberal. Mr. Torricelli appears on the computer screen, saying that he supports a ''variety of positions that are liberal.'' The man clicks three icons, ''crime,'' ''welfare'' and ''taxes.'' Each time, text appears describing Mr. Torricelli's ''too liberal'' positions. The ad closes with the words ''Foolishly Liberal'' flashing on the computer screen. THE SCRIPT -- Net Surfer: ''O.K., let's see, liberal . . . liberal . . . Torricelli.'' Mr. Torricelli: ''I certainly have a variety of positions that are liberal.'' Net Surfer: ''All right, let's see what your liberal positions are. Torricelli voted to let violent criminals go free on technicalities. . . . That's too liberal. Torricelli doesn't want people to work for their welfare benefits. He is a liberal. Torricelli voted for the biggest tax increase ever. . . . Now that's very liberal. No doubt about it. Torricelli is foolishly liberal.'' ACCURACY -- Mr. Torricelli was more liberal than 72 percent of House members last year on economics, 78 percent on social issues and 70 percent on foreign policy, the National Journal's Almanac of American Politics said. Mr. Zimmer was more liberal than 49 percent of his colleagues on economics, 54 percent on social issues and 51 percent on foreign policy. Mr. Torricelli voted against allowing the police to bypass the constitutional protections involving unlawful seizures if the police can show they made a ''good faith'' effort to comply. He voted in favor of the final version of the welfare bill, which places a five-year limit on cash benefits. He voted for President Clinton's 1993 budget, which increased taxes by $241 billion over five years, which was the largest tax increase in American history -- by one measure. But an increase signed in 1982 by President Ronald Reagan was actually larger, $286 billion, when adjusted for inflation. SCORECARD -- The word ''liberal'' is used eight times in 30 seconds. To be cast as a liberal is not such a terrible thing in New Jersey, particularly on social issues. Taxes and government spending are another issue, however, and the ad succeeds in artfully misrepresenting Mr. Torricelli's voting record on welfare spending and taxes. JENNIFER PRESTON

headline.main: A 'Net Surfer' Puts a Republican Spin on Torricelli's Record

docs.abstract: Repr Robert G Torricelli, seeking to portray himself as candidate elderly voters can trust, visits senior center in West Orange, NJ; contends that it has been one year since his Republican opponent for US Senate, Repr Richard A Zimmer, voted to cut growth of Medicare program (M)
